qas.question: When did a tribe of Slavs arrive in Central Europe?
Who was the hero who led the Slavs to their new home, according to legend?
What did the ninth century bring?
Whose influence was Rastislav eager to reduce, when he invited  Michael III to send missionaries?
What alphabet did the missionaries bring to the West Slavs?
When did Rastislav of Moravia arrive in Glagolitic?
Who did Constantine and Methodius lead to Central Europe?

plausible_answers.text: in an attempt to reduce the influence of East Francia

qas.question: Why did Cech send out missionaries?

plausible_answers.text: religious and political life in his country

qas.question: What area did Cech think East Francia had too much influence on?
What kind of system was established by Cech?

context: <b5_0>Around the <a0_0>sixth century AD<b5_0/><a0_0/>, <b6_0>a tribe of Slavs<b6_0/> arrived in a portion of Central Europe. According to legend they were led by a hero named <a1_0>Čech<a1_0/>, from whom the word "Czech" derives. The ninth century brought the <a2_0>state of Great Moravia<a2_0/>, whose first ruler (Rastislav of Moravia) invited Byzantine ruler Michael III to send missionaries <b7_0>in an attempt to reduce the influence of <a3_0>East Francia<b7_0/><a3_0/> on <b8_0>religious and political life in his country<b8_0/>. These missionaries, Constantine and Methodius, helped to convert the Czechs from traditional Slavic paganism to Christianity and established <b9_0>a church system<b9_0/>. They also brought the <a4_0>Glagolitic<a4_0/> alphabet to the West Slavs, whose language was previously unwritten. This language, later known as Proto-Czech, was beginning to separate from its fellow West Slavic hatchlings Proto-Slovak, Proto-Polish and Proto-Sorbian. Among other features, Proto-Czech was marked by its ephemeral use of the voiced velar fricative consonant (/ɣ/) and consistent stress on the first syllable.
